2012.08.16 - bottle 33cl   -   bought in Brussels in Chinese supermarket, beer rather bad, chinese supermarket rather good -  yes sil, we have lots of beel - taste of water

330 ml bottle brewed in Czech Republic. Pours clear golden colour with medium-sized foamy white head. Aroma of malt, grassy hops and cardboard. Pretty much the same with the taste. Light bodied, watery mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Malty finish. Definately not super dry as the name says. Quite basic boring lager.

Light fizzy yellow with a frothy white head. Smells of malt, cereal, light hop and sugar. Crisp super dry body thin watery with bread feel in the carbonation. Sweet taste of corn, cereal and malt. Chewy cereal with a slight fruity apple. Basically sugar water with booze.
Bottle. Pale yellow color. medium carbonation. Very malty lager. sweet bitter, but overall watery.

Giallo paglierino pallido con un velo poco persistente di schiuma bianca. Aroma con flebili sentori luppolati e una dolciastra reminescenza di malto; gusto mediamente amaro e debole; corpo molto lieve e struttura acquosa.
Really nice and clean.  Dry, easy drinking, and refreshing. You can tell its a big beer co type by trying it, but it is a step up from BL, CL and ML its nice, clean
Mild aroma has hay mostly. Clear golden color. Short head. Taste has bread, bit butter. Thin flavor. Not much hops. Dry and light. Fizzy carbonation.  Ok and but not that special in any area.
Bottle - typical pale lager yellow with a small head. Had a metallic aroma and taste. Is dry as advertised but not all that great.
500ml can. A clear golden body , medium white head, decent retention. Aroma of grains, hay, a touch of hops. Taste a bit too sour upfront, cereals, grass. Intense carbonation.
Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, light malty, corn and rice. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. Watery. 080712

It's dry like advertised. But little more. Not great but ok. Like a dry bud light

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of the best Japanese beers. Strong, but still light. light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, umami... If interested in Japanese beer, must try this one!
The same as all the other macro pale lagers; it is tasteless, aroma-less, easy to drink. Non offensive but not good either. Slightly better than the American macros.
This beer is better than its American equivalents, but it is not worth the import price.
dry is one way to say it, another is flavorless.  a slight floral nose no real flavor other than a slight bit of cereal with a dry crisp finish
Clear yellow color with pillowy white head. Some metallic and citrus notes on the nose. Palate is crisp and clean. Good, easy drinking beer.

50cl bottle. Pours a clear pale straw colour with medium white head. Foam dissipates fairly quickly leaving only some rings of bubbles. Aroma is grain, grass and skunk. Taste is corn, grainy and skunky. Lively carbonated with thin body. Overall, avoid.

33 cl bottle @ Maruseki, Tampere. Rated on 30.12.2010

Aroma is quite nothing – just grainy malt and hints of sweetish honey. Flavour is kind of dry as the label promises with some grainy malt, hints of grassy malt and corn. Nothing offensive here and pairs fine with many foods and thirst – but bulky stuff anyway.
12 oz bottle with sushi.  Pours a clear light yellow with a good white head.  Aroma of grain.  Taste is light and sweet with malts and grain.
Flesje in een Japans restaurant.  Lichtgeel van kleur, zuurbitter aroma en idem smaak.  Drinkbaar maar niet dat je zegt wat een lekker pilsje.
Ero curioso perchè non costa mica poco, invece noi fenomeni abbiamo decisamente bisogno di importare sta roba...
Surprisingly good beer. Light but with a nice flavor that is best suited to fairly spicy dishes. Drank it to Spanish paella.
Bottle 330 ml. Clear yellow with a small white head. Aroma of grain and corn with hints of citrus. Taste of malt with slight fruitiness. Mouthfeel is watery dry. Carbonation is moderate. Refreshing.
Golden color with a thin white head and a mild grainy aroma. The flavor has hints of citrus and wheat with a moderately malty mouth feel.
Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is malt, light pine and light grass. Flavour is malt, grain, pine and hay.
A very boring beer with some bitterness and a bit sour. Also a not so nice aftertaste that is undetermined. Light yellow in color with a white head.
330ml bottle. Pours pale gold, average white head. lightbody, high carbonation. Some malt and cereal aromas. Dry andbitter finish. Average lager.
I get a terrible headache every time I drink this. I don’t know what it is. It’s a cool version of a dry beer though, you can really taste the rice...  I dont need to taste again.

330ml bottle pours a pale golden color with a small white head that leaves no lacing behind.  Aroma is mild grains and grassy hops.  Taste is light malty sweetness with a sharp but mild hop bitterness that finishes quickly.  A typical macro style lager that is about average.

From Nov 2006: A brown 500ml bottle, which was full of a dry tasting beer, brewed and bottled in the UK. 5%, but not super dry, as stated on my bottle. 

Urine yellow and clear looking, with a few bubbles breaking the surface of an otherwise headless beer. 

No smell, apart from an aroma simular to dishwater. 

Dryish is taste, but not cheek pullingly so, nor lipsmackingly thirst quenshing, just a poor lager. 

Dryness stays, but is not overpowering. 

This was my first and last ’Super Dry Asahi’ unless I am stranded on a Polynesian island and this is all that is available.

500ml can. Ample head dies fast. Lace is good though. Really pale yellow (Lovibond 3/4). As the description says - sharp delivery. Taste is subdued though, making for easy drinking. Great dry palate. Not as carbonated as I had hoped, but good. No memorable parting flavours... Sharp. Dry. Okay. No aroma to speak of.

I get a terrible headache every time I drink this. I don’t know what it is. It’s a cool version of a dry beer though, you can really taste the rice... but it’s not there to make the ingredients cheaper, it’s just what people prefer. Fairly good.
440ml bottle. I think its brewed in Russia. Clear dark yellow color. No head, flat. Metallic aroma. Taste is same, flat, metallic, paper, some weird ending.

For being Japanese "Lite" beer, it is quite enjoyable with the traditional "Lite" beer yellow and a long lasting head.  The beer tastes much better while in Japan.  The one that you find in the states is made in California.
Pours pale golden color with a non lasting white head. Aroma of corn and some fruitiness. Taste is similar. Drinkability is Ok.
Clear light yellow with thick foam head, not lasting long though. Bitter taste with some rice tones. Nice aftertaste, tickling. (Moscow, 201202)
Dark golden, sweet aroma. slight bitter lager, but very fruity. OK with dinner, in the right circumstance

Decent Japanese beer. Pretty similar to Saporro, a little less sweet, and slightly smoother. But mostly forgettable. Had in the bottle.

Little aroma and an almost oily texture to it. Golden yellow with very little head. Not one of the better japanese beers.

12oz bottle.  Macro corny off aroma.  Filtered orange-tan color...thin non-head.  Some dry crispness, but thats about all it has going for it.  Some garbage flavors...butter.  Macro swill...highly unimpressive.
Pours clear and pale with a white head.  Smells of bread and basement.  Taste is very minimal - like slightly sweet and bitter water, not bad, but nothing to it.
Certainly less sweet than your average Euro-lager but less flavoursome as a result. Light-medium bodied with a slick short dry finish. Barely there hop presence. 330ml bottle.
Straw color with a lot of carbonation. It is very watery and remnants of rice and adjunct.
Pours a pale yellow and white head that goes down rather quickly. Aroma of rice and corn. Taste is mostly rice and a bitter finish. Very light bodied.
Standard ricey brew. Not really super dry but dry. Actually quite refreshing. Pale yellow pour, medium head. Excellent with hibatchi.

Originally rated March 2005. This Japanese lager pours a golden-yellow colour with a foamy white head. Retention is not very long, but the lacing is quite thick. Aromas of grain malts. Taste is slightly sweet with hints of grass. Cereal malt finish. Not as dry as I expected, being called the Super "Dry". Pretty good with Thai food (to cool the burn of the food) but that is about it.
Poors a plain yellow with a frothy white head.  No over powering tastes, but is crisp and refreshing when stone cold.

Bottle at a sushi joint. Molsen should just stick to making their own beer, because they’re barely getting that right. The Canadian Asahi is Ashitty. It’s a little bit like a Miller Light with a more bitter finish. Bleh.

Big 1 qt can from half time, poured in pint glass. Light straw yellow color capped by white craggily rock head with fair retention. No aroma. Light buttery cracker sweetness. Slight undulating bitterness. Not to shabby as a session.

2l Big Can. Karakuchi write on this can. Brewed and canned in Japan. Piwo zwyczajne, ryzowo slodowe, jasna pianka, slomkowa barwa, profil chmielowy znikomy.

Bottle. Brewed in Czech Republic. lepsza od wersji japonskiej, troche w styl czeski podchodzi, barwa nieco ciemniejsza, piana trwalsza, zdecydowanie bardziej chmielny to lager niz z tej ogromnej puszki.
Tap @ Sapporo Teppenyaki. Rich sparkling golden yellow with a big foamy head. Corn aroma. Dry cereal corn flavour. Quite sharp. Would have been better if served colder.
Clear gold with a decent white head that disappears relatively quickly. Little to no lacing. Smells slightly of hops and rice. Taste is not truly bad, there’s just very little of it.
Not bad for a light beer.  Similar to any American light beer, light malt aroma, clear pour.  Taste is malt, no hops.  Over OK when compared to an American light beer.

golden colour, very clean and pure looking. the head is a silky thin white layer. the aromascape does not offer much, but there is a light presence of hops and malt (yes, not very precise) and the overall presence is very clean and fresh. not really anything for the nose here, but at least it’s pure. the palate is indeed very crispy and fresh. through that the malt and rice can be detected well and work with the palate nicely. the sweetness is mild and complements the malt well. this lager does not bend towards the unpleasant flowery tones i dislike. might work well with food and "general drinking for getting there.."
remains fresh and rather crisp

Golden amber with a fast-disappearing head and no lace - very flat looking.  Taste is mostly an adjunct (Corn or rice?) with a fizzy finish.  Very little going on and hardlt worth un-capping.  No redeeming qualities.

Super sexy beer. I love it long time. Not as good as MOA. Great date. What a guy

Light yellow color with minimal head. Not much in the aroma department. Taste of faint malt. Good drinkability if served very cold.

Bottle (33cl) from Vinmonopolet, Oslo. Clear, golden colour. Fingerthick white head that diminishes quickly. Aroma of malt, sweet corn, hint of caramel and metal. Light body, soft carbonation. Sweetish taste with some acidity, finishes dry and unpleasantly papery.
can. pale yellow  white head    . slight aroma only of hay    taste is very dry   some grass   and metallic twang to it    . watery body    nothing to make it stand out
clear and pale yellow colour. almost no aroma. some biscuit or something like dried hay aroma. little flavour. enough said.
33cl bottle. Poured clear golden with a creamy, lasting white head. Aroma has grain, hay and rice. Flavor is grain, sweet malt and carboardish notes. High carbonation, light.

Bottled. Pours golden with a small white head. Smells malty and boiled vegetables. Tastes bread malty and bitter.

Very plain beer. Crisp and dry without much flavour. Ive found that putting soy sauce in it improves it immensely
Uncomplicated beer which is good for sessions as it lacks any overly aggressive flavours, yet has better length than a lot of other lagers.
33 cl, bottled. Pours clear yellow with a snow white head. Aroma: Faint malt, hints of herbs. Taste: Sweetish, some bitterness. Palate: Light, high carbonation. Good drinkability.

mellow grass and lemon in the nose. flavour dominated by sweet malt, but not lets get carried away - there’s not a lot going on! quite fizzy.
it looks decent for its style. there is soem colour from the malt.

This beer poors bubbly with a light brown texture and a big and frothy head. It has a wheaty smell but a watered down simple flavor that is more hydrating then enjoyable. This is followed by a bitted dry after taste that thankfully is abrupt.
Pale yellow color with a average size white head. Almous no aroma. Very thin and slightly malty taste.

Pours a yellow with a frothy white head. Aroma is malt and brewing ceral. Taste is pretty much the same a lingering sweetness. Ultra crisp as common with these Japanese lagers. Quaffable but not worth the extra price that always seems to come with it.

Golden yellow pour white head .... aroma is of grains, sweet malts, and a little metallic .... taste of grain, sweet corny malts, rice and light metal ... crappy light hop ...... super dry more like super crap

07/02/2012 Sydney. As mentioned earlier: nothing interesting about this beer. Just a real crisp, fresh session beer. A very refreshing, easy to drink lager.

1 liter mega-can! Straight from the can, so no appearance description. Some aroma notes emitting from the small hole in the can... Mostly corn.  The only reason I bought this beer was because of its awesome 1 liter size. It drinks ok.

Completly and entirely bland. Christ, is this even beer?!? I’d like to say more, but it’s like pouring a whole lot of cold nothing into my mouth. Atleast it didn’t taste foul.

Light yellow with a good white head. Smells like white rice and fresh floral notes. Taste is clean and simple, with sweet malts, and dry hops. Creamy and fresh texture. This is a good simple beer.

Not really a huge fan of either taste or aroma, to be honest the whole beer was lackluster

Gold with a white head. Aroma is corn and a malt. Taste is corn. Refreshing. B@H

Served very cold.  Not too much in the smell, possibly a slight grainy note.  Golden straw colour with bubbles streaming up and an initial thick white head.  The taste is as the name suggests "super dry", crisp and refreshing and would be thirst quenching on a hot day.  Overall a tasty lager and in the correct situation something that can be enjoyed.

Served ice cold, light straw coloured, topped with a thick white head. High carbonation with rice and slight hops. The only purpose it really serves is to quench your thirst and cool you down.

Pale golden color. High carbonation. Low bitterness. Corn and barley aroma.

Nice notes of barley in this beer. Crisp - and I find it quite refreshing. Very drinkable.

Smell of maize and.. rubber? Pale colour, big white head. Sharp to start with, very watery afterwards. Aroma of rubber.
Bottle at a Japanese sushi restaurant.  Slight fruity aroma.  Mild dry flavor.  High carbonation.  Nothing offensive.

500ml bottle from Tesco, pleasant aroma and a very good taste, it’s two strongest points. Appearance dark amber with head quickly disappearing to nothing unfortunately and very few bubbles at all. Nice on the palate and a beer I did enjoy overall despite some flaws. I would recommend.
Light head, golden. Faintswwwt nose with some fruitiness. Medium body and length. Light. taste simple not unpleasant just booring
Bottle from Alko. Pretty basic but still good quality Asian style mass lager with absolutely no suprises.
From a bottle. A little sweet. Pretty much what one would expect from a shitty lager. It is what it is
Amber, almost fluorescent. White fizz on top. Not much to talk about here - There is a mild malty scent, but not much else. Salty and dry. Goes with japanese food, but a bit bland as a drink.

Location/Date:Bottle at Hanaro in Bethesda.



Appearance: Pours an average clear orange copper.
 

Aroma: Aroma is of semi-stale beer.
 

Taste:Tastes like a below average pale lager, slightly skunky.
   

Palate:Light body.



Summary: A beer from Japan to have with Sushi - and a Japan tick! Otherwise, nothing exciting here.
Bottle.  Pours pale yellow with a small white head.  Very light aroma and flavor.  Mostly hints of grain and light malts.  Bland but not offensive.
Bottle. Clear golden colour. Hard to catch any aroma. Not so much taste at all. Weird experience.

33cl bottle. Pours a golden with a decent white head if poured into narrow glass. Nose : bread and milk like aromas. Floral notes. Little cherry in the background. Sip : Water body with a little carbonation. Quite sour clove on top of all flavors. Tastes like sake shot added in it ;  pity it has only 5%. Buerk.

From a 330 ml bottle imported to germany. Yellow/gold with a medium head. Lively carbonized and refreshing but quite boring taste and smell. A bit malty and a little bitter. Almost no interesting notes. As the name says: super dry at the palate.

On keg at the Republic Bier Halle, Glasgow. Pours a golden colour with a thick white head. Aroma of yeast, caramel and rice. Rice flavour also with caramel and grassy hops. Moderate carbonation and CO2 prickle. A little too fizzy for me.

[bottle at Wagamama, Edinburgh] I really don’t mind Asahi – pours clear gold with a steady stream of rising carbonation. Decent white head. Mild aromas of grain and general bitterness. Very easy to drink, thin aftertaste, but it’s a mass produced lager – does what it does well. Crisp finish [04112011]

Bottle, noodle bar in Tokyo. Pale golden yellow colour. Smells like mass produced lager, has some of the slightly off-putting characteristics of corn/rice flavoured beer, but overall not too offensive and has some malt character.
Pale golden beer with white head. Pretty neutral with some grassy notes. Rice and a little of cardboard. Just a bit too watery.
Bottle - small foamy head, light straw color, smooth dry light malt flavor - OK for a Japanese beer
Sample at KC Beerfest 10-22.  Comes pale yellow with small white head.  Mild aroma of grain and malt.  Taste is light malt, watery.  Not much going on here.

Tasted from bottle into chilled pint glass at a Japanese restaurant. Poured a clear straw color with rocky white head which quickly dissipated, no lace. Typical mass-produced adjunct lager aromas and flavors. At least they admit to the heavy use of corn. Not sure what "Super Dry" refers to; it finishes as crisp and dry as any lager. Fine with rich, spicy Japanese food, but nothing special.
Bottle. Fairly standard larger, probably one of the best I have had from Asia so far. Not much else to say
Pour of pale or light amber. Aromas of grain, light hops, and hay. Flavor of hay and left over stale hops that leads to a slight skunkyness. Lightly bitter, clean, and crisp. Your everyday lager.
not bad, not really good. second best choice at japanese restaurants that only have japanese beer

33 cl bottle.

Pours clear pale golden colour with a large head. Aroma of clove, corn, grass and some light malts. Flavour of butter, dry hay, corn and malts. Light-bodied and straightforward.

2312

Bottle at Apollo Cinema, Piccadilly. Colour is amber but with a bit of a copper tinge. Nose is barely discernable, getting virtually nothing other than a metallic, minerally smell. Taste is grainy malt, carbonated fizz with a slight dry bite. Dullest beer I’ve had in a long time.

330 ml bottle.BBE 1.6.2012.

Pours a pale yellow colour with a small, thick, white head. Aroma of corn with some weak maltiness. Weak flavour of corn, dry malts and dry bitter hops. Light bodied, thin mouthfeel and a light finish with weak malts and hops. Pretty much low on everything but still unoffensive. Refreshing as well.

Light yellow beer with a medium and white head. Aroma is malty, some honey sweetness, quite refreshning aroma. Taste is quite sweet and malty, and actually nothing else, hint of hoppyness. Quite light to drink, nice carbonation. Basicly, good and fresh beer, but that’s all special, no need to try another time.

500 ml bottle. Pale yellow colour, very clear, with almost no head and zero lacing. Grainy aroma, a super light breadiness, no hops presence at all. Can’t really find any taste in this beer. At least it is slightly refreshing if drinked right out of the fridge. Still...boring.
Bottle 330ml. Light golden with a foam that disappears quickly. Aroma slight citrus feel. Medium carbonnation. Disappointing as expected.
brewed under licence at Shepard neame. Minimal aroma. Sweet malty body and dry finish.
Bottle. Fizzy, yellow and low in flavour. Not a criticism. As far as transparent yellow, mass produced lagers go, this is a good un’. Crisp and clear. Fizzy. Impressive in absolutely no respect.
Bottle. Corn, rtie, alcoholic harshness, dust. Gold body, white head. Fairly sweet. Dry finish. Decent lager.
En nästan helt obefintlig doft och smak, kanske en aning touch av gräs om jag lägger go’viljan till. Inget mycket att ropa hurra för
330 ml bottle. Clear pale yellow colour, thin white head. Mild, grainy malty aroma. The flavour is light, malty, with a mildly grassy-hoppy finish. Boring.
Hopfig-würziger und grasiger Geruch. Start hopfenwürzig. Mitte würzig weiterführend, leider etwas brotig und pappig. Abgang dann moderat bittertrocken. Geht so.

I don’t know why everyone is so down on this beer. Asahi has some watery nonsense out there, but this Super Dry is a good, wheaty, mild, very drinkable and refreshing beer.

It appears that the pretense and snobbery of craft-brew-Gestapo affectations has overpowered the ability to objectively analyze something’s enjoyability. Mild, refreshing beers are not bad, they’re a different style, and we should look to rate beers according to how well they embody a style or accomplish a purpose, and this beer’s purpose is to be well carbonated, light, and refreshing— which it is through and through.

These Asahi brews are certainly a pleasant surprise! To be honest, I was half expecting them to be on the skunky side but they have proven me wrong and are good brews to enjoy! This brew poured up a clear pale golden yellow body with a white frothy head that quickly dissipated to a thin bubbly sheen and left marginal lacing. Aromas and flavors are genuinely almost like good sake in this light-bodied brew with a clean, dry finish with no harsh aftertastes. Definitely an easy brew to drink and not get that bloated feeling afterwards (unless you down a case or so!).
Pours a thin head, light straw colour, hoppy but not much else going on. Lacks bite

Bottle 330ml. A clear yellow colour with a small white head. An aroma of malt and caramel. Some toasted notes. The taste is medium sweet. A light body, watery texture, soft carbonation and an abrupt finish.

Bottle. It doesn’t have a strong smell, but something about the taste is extremely refreshing. Carbonation balances the taste. It’s good to have with fish and casual meals. This is one of my go-to beers.
Metallic and oily malt aroma. Sharp and dry malt taste with a watery and bland finish. Lacks really a hop taste! This beer might work with Japanese food, but alone it is a disaster!
Bright yellow colour, little head. Hardly any smell, pilsner like. Weird taste, pilsener but also some cardboard notes. Too much carbo, dry.
Aroma is the typical pale lager malt. Taste is also bland malt, but a little more character than the mass pale lagers.

On tap at local sushi bar. Pours out a light pale yellow with a nice head. Aromas of grains corn malts and rice. Tastes  follows the aromas and is fairly indistinct.  I love this type of beer with hamachi  spicy tuna and salmon. Finishes crisp and dry with a slight sweetness to offset the soy and wasabi. .
Not much in aroma or flavor, a bit of grain, otherwise a rather plain/mildly flavorless but not nasty pale lager.

Asahi Super Dry has a thick, white head and a clear, bubbly, straw appearance, with a decent amount of lacing left behind. The aroma is of indistinguishable grains and some slight sweetness. Taste is initially of malt, but then at the middle to the end of the sip one encounters a partially sweet alcohol flavor, and this is fairly bold. The aftertaste is grassy and stinging. The mouthfeel is light and watery, and Asahi Super Dry finishes crisp, clean, refreshing, and super dry. Overall, I really like this beer, and I recommend it. RJT
500ml bottle, brewed by Sheps.  Pours gold with a large frothy head.  Aroma is corn and a touch of sweetness.  Taste is mostly corn throughout with a dry finish.  Really refreshing though.

Re-rated 8/15/15. I’ve been trying to understand some of the design ethics behind the beers I’m sampling. I guess this was intended to have no flavor or character other than a subtle malty sweetness up front - becuas eit really has no other notable characteristics (including negative ones.) It sort of achieves that goal and really nails the "dry" part - i.e. no taste at all at the end of the swallow. Within the context of its intended taste this is probably a 4.5 or so... as a beer that I may want to drink it rates rather low.

Pour form a 24 oz bottle. Pale clear brew with three fingers of white head. Not much aroma. Taste is very light grains at the start with a very dry finish - no bitter, just dry. It does what it says it does.
Bottle @ home shared with DutchDrebus. Clear yellow pilsener color, small white head. Not much smell, just a slight hint of pilsener malts. Ok taste, ok carbo, low body.
Very light, smooth texture. Not overpowering, but enough of a gentle bitterness to add some palatability. Flavor also light, but leaves a bit to be desired
It smells horrible, but its very smooth going down so it isnt all that bad just your basic pale lager
Not much in aroma or flavor, a bit of grain, otherwise a rather plain/mildly flavorless but not nasty pale lager.

Oj mist da habe ich wieder nicht aufgepasst und einen Tschechen statt nen Japaner gekauft, ärgerlich! Naja da die Rezeptur und so vielleicht aus Japan kommt zähl ich Japan mal als mein Land Nr.18! Es schmeckt wässrig, dazu ein bisschen nach Hopfen und Reis. Der Nachgeschmack ist säuerlich reissig. Fazit: Nicht gerade lecker aber hier gilt wie so oft: Wenn man es in Japan in der Hitze trinken würde, würde es vielleicht besser passen. Obwohl ist es in Japan so warm?? Wirklich ärgerlich der war echt teuer....
	
Test vom 15.3.2009, Gebinde: Dose 	Noten: 8,5,6,5,5,5 - 5,45
It’s hard to get down and it’s really skunky. It’s weird concidering they use corn and rice in their beer, woudn’t buy it again.
I ordered this beer while having lunch at a tepanyaki restaurant. It’s definitely not a great beer but if you want something neutral to go with a meal, it will do the trick. I won’t order it again.

Mercifully consumed at a crap sushi hole with white servers. Clear gold wig a small compact white cap. Barely any aroma but there is some grains and a bit of wheat and slight fruit..... or is that the taste? Pretty much the same aside from a good bitterness. Decent brew after all.

21.4 oz. bottle- Pours pale golden with a thin ugly head, aroma is grainy, some citrus, fresh. The flavor is not suprisingly pale lagerish, it is smooth, drinkably simple, but light and flavorless at the same time, as far as pale lagers go, I have had worse, alot worse. Will never drink again!
(can) (Hong Kong) clear pale yellow, tall white head; sweetish aromas of corn , clean flavour, simple but not too watery, unremarkable but not quite as bad as most asian beers

I like this. This beer is clean, very drinkable and most of all very refreshing. Would make a great session beer. This in fact is one of those rare beers that can be enjoyed straight from the bottle. A perfect summer-time thirst quencher. I can see why the Japanese are so fond of this one.

Pours gold with a large fading head.
Nose shows grassy hops and faint grainy malt with a cardboard character. Pretty soft.
Similar flavours, very light, though theres a big cardboard hit.
Very watery, too much carbonation.
Not complex, very slight hops flavour. Clear. Simple. Not so bad for a Japanese beer.

I suppose if I had tasted this blind I would have been surprised to learn that it was beer at all. It looked like a very thin lager with a big fluffy white head, it hit my palate and was gone. Seriously gone. Thirst slaking, thirst creating and an ideal partner to the food I was eating at the time. I don’t think the low mark that I’m going to give it should dismiss its place in the beer world.
Clear golden with a white, short lived head. Unrevealing aroma. Some light malts comes through. Light sweet and light bitter. Watery. Bland.

Poured a bland bubbly off-yellow body. The smell of funky malts and a touch of honey gave off a sort of bouillon, or chicken broth scent. Pretty funny actually! The taste was just as weird, tasted like corn, hops and fried rice. Twas’ so bad that I actually kind of liked it for its strangeness. That aside, I would rather have a Bud Light.

Finally time to rate this staple Japanese import. Giant quart can (very cool single-serve packaging; not sure why you don’t see this at parties more). Poured a bit into a glass for the review. Head is decent, but settles quickly to a thin white cap. Beer is expected low SRM urine color. Aroma is adjunct. I hesitate to say skunky, because it’s in a can, but maybe I just automatically associate that with import lager now. Flavor is light, sweet, crisp, and dull. Very drinkable. Hard to say where this would fall in a blind taste test with light lagers. Maybe a bit more hop content and bitterness in the finish, which contributes to the dry sensation, but other than that, not much going on. Back to drinking this from the giant can...

Didn’t expect much and I got what I expected. Nose was chicken broth and corn. Slight yeasty smell. Off. It actually looked like chicken stock, too. Slight head. Tasted like brown rice cooked in chicken broth. Might be good with some food but as a stand alone it is horrible.
Was not impressed with this won’t be buying it again not graet tasteing or smelling
Can. Medium head with medium duration. Color is pale golden. Aroma and taste are malt, grain and hops.

A decent above average lager in my opinion, the beer has some interesting fruity notes that are not over the top, providing an extra layer of interest in the beer.  No corn/dms aroma or flavor in this beer, which puts it above many similar beers in my opinion.

piss yellow with a foamy head that eventually fades away, , smells cornbready in a way, not too strong at all, taste is dry, bitter, a bit off, but weak and ricey. harsh but filling mouthfeel, idk, wont bother with again.

Pale Lager month installment number 12: I’ve always been fascinated by the whole "dry" beer thing... is there seriously a market niche of folks who drink primarily macro pale lager and seek out a beer that is specifically "dry"? I’m not saying that dry lager is a bad thing, just wondering what’s behind the marketing with these beers. 
Asahi Super Dry pours... you guessed it! pale and yellow. The head is nice though, very big and tight and fluffy on the top... pretty well retained too. The aroma is very one dimensional, and that dimension is pretty damned boring, akin to a very watered down Riesling with some white grape and mild floral aspects. It’s miles from smelling offensive though, that’s for sure.  The flavor is moderately (not super) dry with a mild bit of fruitiness up front and a bit of light bitterness, overall this is very similar to seltzer water. Again it’s not offensive, but it’s not much of anything really.
I like it but don’t love it. Nice appearance and initial taste but is let down by its after taste and aroma. Still worth a try though.
Not bad. Wasn’t actually brewed in Japan which was a shame. Just your basic pale lager. Quite enjoyed the bottle none the less. Very smooth, small bubbles but nothing to write home about.

It seems like no matter what country you go to, their best-selling beer is a pale adjunct lager. I’ve never understood this since these beers are very difficult to brew consistently and they lack flavor. The only thing going for them is their drinkability. And when it comes to Japan things aren’t any different, as Asahi Super Dry is their "No. 1 Beer" according to the can. While I’m not an expert on Japanese cuisine or culture by any means, I still don’t get why this is the top beer there.

I poured a 500ml can into a football-shaped glass.

Appearance: Dark gold hue, almost crystal clear with slight haze. Large carbonation bubbles visible en masse. Forms a surprisingly large, bright white foamy head which eventually dissolves and leaves no lacing.

Smell: Since this is from a can you wouldn’t expect skunkiness, but I did detect a slight green bottle-like aroma here. I find macro pale lagers all tend to have a scent like this whether canned or bottled. There’s a slightly sweet rice scent and an otherwise generic-to-the-letter cardboard "beer smell" here. It’s not wretched, but it’s far from appealing.

Taste: Based on the appearance and smell, I literally "braced for shock" as I took my first swig of Asahi Super Dry. I was pleasantly surprised that my palate was NOT assaulted with anything sour and foul-tasting as is often the case with those green bottled lagers. Not that it was hit with anything pleasurable, either. What’s most prominent about this beer is that there’s nothing prominent about it at all. The palate is bland, neutral, pain, mild and whatever other adjectives you want to use to describe a lack of flavor.

Since this is a Japanese macro adjunct it’s no surprise it’s made with rice as an adjunct, yet it doesn’t taste nearly as sweet as its American counterpart Budweiser. It has a slight startchy-like flavor akin to crackers, which is slightly sweet. This increases as it warms, but at a point the green bottle-like components begin to come out too, with a sour, green apple tang. It’s tolerable to be sure, but there’s really nothing to enjoy about this beer’s palate.

Mouthfeel: Starts off as a typical fizzy yellow beer with plenty of carbonation burn when drank very cold and quickly. Softens up to a more watery consistency as it warms. 

Drinkability: For beer that calls itself "Super Dry" I find Asahi to be anything but. It’s actually a little refreshing, but then again it’s a bland lager so that could be due to its overtly watery qualities. At 5% ABV it’s very drinker-friendly, although I probably wouldn’t session it unless I had access to plenty of salty snacks and used this to quench my thirst.

Overall, a mediocre/below average macro lager. There are other brews of the style that are far worst, but I’m still not giving this one a free pass.

33cl bottle at Sumo’s, Scheveningen.
Decent white head.  Normal pils colour.  Ok.
Fresh, crisp and clear pretty much sums this one up. Rather good for the beer it’s trying to be. Damn expensive per pint in Perth though
Astringent. Not much aroma. Sort of like Coors, with a bit more flavor. Blech.
Bottle. Light gold pour with a quickly dissipating white head. Faint grain aroma. Somewhat dry on taste. Flavor is slightly sweet and grainy.

He probado esta cerveza muchas veces, normalmente cenando en algún restaurante japonés de la península o viajando en zonas de Asia... y que queréis que os diga, no merece comentario alguno. Una cerveza de gran consumo más.
(1 L oil can)  Well described commercially.  A perfect choice for sushi or Japanese meals to accentuate the food without overpowering.  My choice for dinner at Blossom.  Well played.

Bottle. Light golden, small and fully diminishing head. Light malty-grainy and
lightly sweetish aroma, some grassy hoopyness. Body is light to medium, malty-grainy and dryish flavor, grassy hoppyness. Finish is average, malty and dryish, grassy hoppyness. Light and dryish lager, OK hoppyness considering the light body.

Can. Pours a clear yellow color with a small fizzy head. Aroma is of grains, faint grassy hops and some sweet malts. Flavor is again the sweet matls, grains and slightly grassy hops with a faint metallic note. The body is light with a watery mouthfeel. Overall all your usual below average Pale Lager.

Bottle.  Pours a clear pale golden color with a white head.  Nose is slightly sweet with weak grains and adjuncts.  Light body, slight initial sweetness with grains and rice, just a hint of citrus.  Finish is dry, only a hint of bitterness, somewhat metallic.
Light grain aroma. Clear light golden color with a small white head. Light flavor with a touch of bitterness at the end.

This is the first beer review to be written after I left Japan in the wake of Japan’s massive Tohoku earthquake.  I’ve given pale macro lagers like these a lot of criticism, casting aspersions on their bland flavors, underwhelming palate, and criminal prices. They deserve it.  Japan’s mass produced beers have unwaveringly followed the flavors and business models of other mass been producers, but at a higher price point.  Even so, Japan’s mega-breweries are irrefutably icons of the Japanese economy.  Every tiny restaurant, izakaya, bar, pub and even some homes are decorated with logos from these breweries.  They are drilled into every civilian’s head, day and night, through print and television ads.  Ebisu, Kirin and Sapporo stand atop buildings, high above the concrete labyrinth below in Japan’s metropolises, bright and gaudy, almost foppish with their lights apoplectically blinking, advertising the golden juice just a few paces away in some patient convenience store or bar.  It is everywhere except your gut. For me, the most eminent of these dokodemo, itsudemo logos is Asahi.  I have no evidence that Asahi has a larger advertising budget, or has more images of its logo smeared around inhabited areas per meter than its competitors.  The difference between Asahi and other mass market brews is simple: the can.  Asahi is raw, nostalgic, and industrial.  It doesn’t hide its aluminum skin under paints or colors.  When you look at a gallery of beers in a refrigerator, everything else is garbed in golds and colors, looking mature, but also exciting, and even a little desperate.  The Asahi is saturnine, stalwart, and sudsy.  It eschews the glitter and adheres to its roots - a metal can filled with beer.  One more grade of sheer brutal manliness and Asahi would be serving their beer out of tin pales and slop buckets.  It glows with the soft nostalgia of Showa, and is solidly dependable is an incredibly mediocre beer available almost anywhere whenever a poker game or a video game challenge breaks out.  Budget constraints suspended my beer drinking hobby while I was in Japan, but a can or bottle of Asahi made a great drink when I was sitting down with a bowl of ramen, or lounging around with some senbei crackers.  It’s a social and cultural pillar, and while my palate will beg me to stop, I know that future trips to Japan will see me shelling out yen for a can of the cold stuff.
Can’t believe i haven’t gotten to this one yet.  A pale lager with hint of grains, ok for what it is
Yes, me like. Good looking, ok smelling and fine tasting. Fresh. Bootle bought at supermarket in Thailand.

Belle bière dorée et cristaline sous un col mousseux immaculé.  Des arômes très (trop?) légers ce céréales et de résine qui se cachent derrière un goût métalique et caoutchouteux de la canette.  Très peu amère.  Très effervescente et un peu mince, finale abrupte et légèrement sucrée.  Mal pris, dans le désert, j’en prendrais probablement une autre...
Can: Pale golden, quickly collapsing small white head; grainy cardboardy nose; light bitter-sweet flavour, very light bodied; short perfumed sweetish-bitter finish. Neither dry nor super....
2009 rating. Yellow color with small white head. Light malty aroma. Taste, watery, notes of sweetness. Bad.

bottle@home from a nearby night shop: bottle describes it as Japan’s premium beer & super & dry but that is all pretty much nonsense, generic, little bit dry, asian lager, tastes a bit artificial/rice but overall bland and forgetable
I like it as a nice asian lager, I feel it was very similar to Saporro, stil good
Can, from lcbo, pretty easy drinking, not much life to this beer but it was better then some similar offerings, I would have this again, just nothing special about this one
Can. Clear yellow body with thin head that retains. Pretty nice after a hard days work. After taste fades right away but the little flavour that comes through is ok.

0.33l bottle. Pours a clear pale body with the typical thin white lager head. Aroma is faint malt, dry water and dust. Funny, but this tastes nothing. Watery fizzing texture tasting water with perhaps a little sweet aftertaste. Not dry at all and definitely not super dry!

Orange copper with hardly any aroma but maybe a faint citrus hop tang? .... thats a stretch though. Taste is similar but the flavor that does come out is no dice for me. Metallic and musty, not a fan. It doesn’t have the interest OR the drinkability going for me.
2 liter bottle. Nose of cooked rice and corn. Taste is the same. Some gross sweetness. Not very good but far from being as bad as  say, Molson Canadian.

I had never enjoyed Asahi on draft until I was in Tokyo in the middle of July heat, and every little noodle shop in Shinjuku had a keg of Asahi and a fridge full of chilled mugs.  Asahi on draft is absolutely delicious for a hot day, a crisp lightly malty with a smidge of citrus flavor, sweet but not overpoweringly so.  Not much of a nose on it, nor is it hoppy.   From the bottle/ can it is not nearly as good, but for the two weeks that I was exploring Japan in sweltering 90 degree humidity, there was nothing better than a chilled mug of Asahi.
There are many beers like this. Nothing too special. I’m confident I could not pick it out of a line of similar beers.
Slightly better than other Japanese macro brews it does deliver a slightly dry finish.
Bottle. Pale yellow colour with little head. Slight aroma. Weak, light flavour.

Bouteille de 33cl. Couleur dorée très pale, mousse honnète, tient moyennement. Dominance de maïs, amertume honorable. Une pils qui a quand même un peu de goût, correcte. Trouvée à Auchan - Noyelle Godault.
Bottle. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is little more complex than your other lager. Better mix of malt that does the trick. Taste isn´t too good, too light (it´s a lager...).

500 mL bottle at home poured into a pint glass.  Brewed and bottled by Shepherd Neame.  Golden lager with a healthy head.  Smells a bit lagery, but also has a hint of sulphur which is a little off putting.  Head isn’t too good it looks a bit like washing up bubbles as it subsides.  Tastes a touch malty, a bit metallic, and also has that hint of sulphur (which at least means it tastes slightly different from most average lagers).  I hope the authentic Japanese stuff tastes better than this as its not great.
2/13/11.  16oz bottle.  Clear amber pour with basically no head, just a sizzle of white.  Plain sweet aroma with a sweet fusel caramel flavor.  Meh.
Light gold with a white head. Not bad tasting at all. It has a watery taste mixed with a small grain flavor.

Blaaaaaaaaaaah.  This beer tastes like water.  I will never buy another one of these beers.  I don’t care if this was the last beer left in the world.  I would rather drink straight alcohol or aftershave.

Presentation: It was poured from a 1000ml can into a German Masskrug. The can offers very little info about the beer. There is only a short description. It has no freshness date or abv%.

Appearance: A bright golden colored beer with great clarity and some carbonation fills my big German mug. On top I got a tall bright white head of foam that quickly faded to a thin wispy covering and as I drank it only made some light spotty lacing.

Smell: In the nose there is very little to pick up. All I got was a light cracker like maltiness with a wisp of grassy hops.
Taste/Palate: The flavor is simple, light and refreshing. I get a mild dry biscuity/cracker like malt base with a light kiss of hop bitterness. The finish is dry and a tad astringent. It has a light body with light carbonation and a thin watery feel.

Notes: Simple plain and yes dry.
Bottle. Nice refreshing beer with sweet, hoppy characters. Good thirst quencher.

birra dorata con bella schiuma bianca e fine !poco persistente e poco aderente!olfatto e gusto scarsi un po di malto un po di luppolo finche dura la schiuma. leggermente fruttata?retrogusto scarso solo un po di amaro durante la degluttizione e una fastidiosa sensazione di farina poi!la bottiglia invita all’acquisto ma solo per una volta!
nothing too great. had at sushi restaurant...................................................
can, courtesy of pivnizub. Clear pale yelow, mid-sized white head. Malty nose. Malty, dusty, light-bodied and thin.

Very refreshing - an excellent beer given it’s mass production.
Good with food, great palate.

Surprised at bad reviews, this is a very good beer, its light and tasty and a refreshing brew. Has a nice aroma and very mouthfilling. This beer was manna from heaven after a year of substandard Korean beers. I drank it at a layover at Kansai airport on my way back to NZ. It was expensive (550yen)

The beer in glass is golden yellow with a fine, flat head. Smells revealed hoppy grainy. The beginning part is sweet hoppy and very sugary. The aftertaste is again grainy, also sweet. The further course is still very sweet and in fact a bit dry and difficult to digest.

Can- Pours a pale golden color with abig head and some lacing. Light aroma of some grain. Unoffensive. Taste is sort of bland with a bit of a metallic flavor. Somewhat dry finish. Light body, well carbonated. quite clean and crisp. Typical "Dry Beer". Seems to go best with Asian food.
22oz bottle in shaker.  Pours light golden. Aroma of a pale lager.  Nothing special here, but very dry like it says.  Decent

Pours golden with a little head.  Kind of a light aroma but, nothing too appealing.  Taste and Palate.........there’s just nothing much to talk about.  This really isn’t a good beer.  I don’t think I would enjoy it on a hot sunny day.

Bottle, part of an import pack I got for Christmas.  Pours a dark yellow with a quickly dissipating white head.  Tastes like other macro lagers....straw/wheat/rice flavor.  Not much flavor in it, everything fades quickly.  Meh.

Pours clear pale golden with huge fluffy white head. Weak aroma of malts and hops. Crispy dry mouthfeel. Flavor is very dry and hoppy, nice, with malty tones. Watery palate. Finishes short. Good beer that doesn’t fill you up and you can drink a bunch of, yet doesn’t taste like piss.

It pours a golden color with a white head and some string like lacing. It has a good solid amount of carbonation.

On the nose I am getting mostly rice and a few grassy notes.

The flavor isn’t really anything special. It’s mostly similar to euro pale lager’s. But with this I am getting a lot of rice,some grain’s,grass. I have to say some sweetness thrown in the mix.

It finishes with crisp with a little grassy from the hops. It is pretty dry on the finish but really almost too dry. If this is the best the Japanese have to offer in beer. Makes sense why they go crazy when they come to North america for beer.
con sushi en japan inn.  los japoneses no tienen muchas opciones asi que n modo

Pours clear pale golden with huge fluffy white head. Weak aroma of malts and hops with tones of dry hay. Crispy dry mouthfeel. Flavor is very dry and hoppy, nice, with malty tones. Watery palate. Finishes dry tart, quite shortlived.

Appearance :pale, golden, hazy, rocky head, white foam, 
Taste :light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, 
The palate:full body, oily feel, fizzy, 
Aroma :caramel, bread, nuts, Hops,floral, grass, herbs, earthy, leaves, butterscotch, cooked vegetables, ginger, rotten eggs, smoke,
Bottle. Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt and grain. Taste is very dry and a little watery.

Very clear, straw color.  Thin, white head that was gone almost before I finished pouring.  Scant amount of lacing left on the glass.  Few bubbles coming up from the bottom.  Very light hops in the nose.  Getting, what I find to be, a wet corn or wheat smell.  Somewhat off putting actually.  This beer actually smell kind of stale.  The taste reveals the corn with a touch of hop bitterness.  Not much.  Some astringency is a bit distracting.  Got a bit of "the funk" rearing its head in the taste also.  Mouthfeel was thin, but surprisingly rather dry.  Not much is left on the palate however.  It is smooth and could be somewhat refreshing if need be.  Doesn’t feel bad by any means.  Well...  I like to give each beer a fair review and I respect all brewers, but i probably won’t be visiting this beer again.  Some may like it and I’m sure it has its place, but it’s just not the beer for me.  I’m better off having tried it though.

(500ML Bottles.) 
 Nice hypnotic Japenese writting .  I got 12 bottles cheap and maybe I was in trace or maybe this shit was surprisingly flavoursome.   Its not pretending to be an elegant north German Pils , its a dry , buttery -somewhat sweet soulless lager intended to be drank fast  without much pondering.

Aroma: malty & grainy
Appearance: yellow with large white head
Taste: malt & grainy again with a dry aftertaste
Palate: dry & the aftertaste leaves bubbles on the tongue that evaporate in your mouth
Overall: A bog standard lager beer, delivers exactly what it says; a dry pale lager.

Serving: Bottle (500ml)
Bottle at a Japanese sushi restaurant. Extremely average lager. Nothing special to remark about it. Just plain simple exactly what the rest of the world would call ’beer’.
Pale yellow, small head. Grain and malt aromas, tastes like grain and some hoppy hints. Dry and reaaaaallly industrial in every way. Not a fan of the finish either, astringent industrial nastiness.

Fújj!!! Ez egy átverés! Nem éri meg az ára felét sem. (425 Huf volt.) Olyan az illata mintha megposhadt volna a maláta amiből főzték. Habja az szinte nincs, kiöntve felpezseg, mint valami pezsgő és el is tűnik. Híg, vízízű valami keserű utóízzel. Nem is pocsékolom az időm tovább. NEVERMORE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
u.i.: az általam kóstolt egy cseh verzió volt szóval ha egyszer kijutok japánba esetleg adok neki még egy esélyt... talán...

44cl bottle. A version brewed by Baltika in Russia. Pale yellow, small head. As a matter of fact, it really is super dry. Also, it is overly carbonated and then there is some sourness in the finish. Must be the rice.

Bottle:
White head that disappears quick.
Yellow golden colored beer.
Smell aroma’s of malts, grains, wheat, spices and some hops.
Taste is quite similar to smell, bit watery and not much body.
1/2 liter cans at a reception. Smells and tastes like white rice with an aftertaste that resembles a $9 handle of vodka.

Draught at a chain izakaya in Osaka. Finally got around to rating this. Light hop and light malt aroma. Crisp, light, smooth body, clean, dry flavor. Nothing off, very drinkable, very innocuous. Slips gently on, for sure.
No way,not my kind of thing.Dull watery taste and no aroma at all.The foam disappears right away.I was expecting better things from this,but 100% disappointed.
Yellow pour with white head. Aroma is grains. Taste is dry, little malt, a little crisp.

The logo looks foreign, but that’s about the only departure from any sort of american lager (well, except for the elevated price). Dry, relatively without flavor. Finish could be described as clean...or just uninteresting. Only interesting for novelty’s sake in the extra large tallboy format.
Just another foreign version of an plain American Pale Lager. Typical, nothing special or even relatively good.

Bottle. Light notes of grain and herbs and a hint of cooked vegetables. Head is frothy, pure white with some good lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is sparkling clear gold. Flavor is mostly all acidic and a little bitter in the end. Palate is light, dry and has a lively carbonation. Not much to it, but a nice beer to pair with tepanyaki.
Tried on bottle together with sushi at Raw, Stockholm. Quite boring lager, did not take away flavour from the food but that is about as much upside as the beer presented. Tasteless, watery, bland.
Bottle. Light gold pour with a quickly dissipating white head. Faint grain aroma. Somewhat dry on taste. Flavor is slightly sweet and grainy.
If you would like a very dry, crisp lager. That does not have much flavor you will like this. Not too offensive and both grows and wilts on you. Serving: Bottle

From can and with a small short glass.  Clear gold color with almost no white head.  Aroma of light malts and corn.  Flavors of light malts, rice and corn.  Tastes are not that great, light carbonation, not that dry either.

Bottled.  Poured clear straw golden with a stark white head.  The aroma picked up touches of lemon zest over sweet corn and honey.. pleasant enough.  The flavor found corn, pale malts, and honey at the core.. kind of sharp on the edges with a combo of carbonation and grassy bitters.. finished dry with sticky corn and some of the aforementioned sharpness.  Light-bodied with only OK flow across the palate.. smooth middle.. this was very drinkable, but not worth another look.

Pours totally clear yellow.  Decent amount of head that doesn’t disappear immediately.  Aroma of cereal and bottle depot.  Not much in the way of hops.  Nothing too assertive.  Nice amount of carbonation.  Rather boring.

Bottle. Pours a clear yellow beer with a white head. The aroma is some malt and hops with grass. The flavor is malt, sweetness and some bitterness. The palate is slightly bitter. Overall a boring and pointless beer.
This is one of the japanese beers that you can find in the japanese restaurants in Madrid. Everything about it has been said. Just a refreshing beer

Bottle. Seconds lasting white head and golden body (darker than other japanese beers). Aroma is malty, but very light. Very watery in mouth, generally sweet and with an extra touch of malt. Thin palate and kind of fizzy, with a dry finish (but not that dry!).

The best japanese beer you can drink in Barcelona’s restaurants; better brewed than others. Still, it tastes like water when combined with japanese food.
Bottle. Golden pour with zero head. Tastes malty, thin, bland, fizz. This was hard work but I did manage to finish it so as not to upset my host.

12 oz bottle from Japanese restaurant.  Pours Corona color with hay, grassy nose and metallic, skunky hoppy taste.  No malt balance at all. I really had to struggle to finish the bottle.  I think I would be better off ordering Heineken.

50cl bottle from a Morrisons. Straw coloured with a loose white head and moderate carbonation; freshy grassy hop aroma;  watery with a sweet cardboard taste; and a cloying finish.Nothing makes this stand out from a standard pale lager.
Bottle @ Itsu, London. Taste like a pilsner, nothing special, somewhat hoppy finish. I don’t regard this one as especially dry. Light-bodied.

Can. Golden pour, medium head.
Aroma is faint malt, some grain and rice.
Flavour is malty, some rice, appropriate hop backbone.
Not too bad.
Bottle. yellow colour with medium creamy white mostly lasting head. Malty aroma. Sweet flavor. Watery palate.
Pours pale orange with a nonexistent head. Aroma is malts, flavor likewise, with a hint of bitterness. Your average cheap lager pretty much.
not too bad, but not something I’d go for for anything again. dry head, a little hop-heavy on the nose, the feel is watery and the taste holds lemon and hay and is very dry.
Can. Sharp hop hit. Finish is as advertised, very dry, which I kinda liked. Lacking in distinction otherwise. Not a bad lager really.

Asahi Breweries, Ltd.--Asahi Super Dry--1999 22 oz. Bottle.  5.00% ABV.  (3.25 / 5.0)  Pilsner?  Clear thin bright golden color.  Crisp light hop front.  Smooth flavorful malt body.  Negligible Japanese off flavors.  Light sweetness in malt is nice.  Finishes with hint of refreshing malt flavor.  Sampled 1/13/2000.

30th May 2010. On tap at the ’Sun Inn’ Kelvedon. Clear gold beer. Dry crisp palate. Dry malt and a little citrus hop that has a distinct metallic edge. Dry finish with more unpleasant metallic things in the aftertaste.

330 ml bottle in Thailand. Pours with a soapy, lace head that dies quickly, and big soda-pop carbonation bubbling up. Metallic aroma. Some life on the palate, but still oddly limp. Very quick finish, and oh so dry--even less flavor as I drank more. Pretty blah beer, and below average in my opinion.
Pretty anonymous international lager, very drinkable but no distinguishable features

Best beer i ever drunk, super dry is the best desciption they could have given it, but the taste is no where near dry, it will stay in your mouth long after the empty glass and will make you want another one, it wont dominate your mouth as well, you can go on eating good food and enjoy it’s aroma as a bonus to possibly every taste. 
a strong flavour, and a good calm buzz as well.
Best beer i know. stands slightly above Efes and Goldstar. and a bit similer in taste if you wish to compare.
Pours standard straw yellow with little head. Almost no aroma. Taste of honey, apple, very crisp. It could just be it was a hot day and i was thirsty but i thought it was very good for a pale lager.

Bottle. Pours a light yellow colour with a thin white head. Cereal malt and grain aroma. Not much going on in the way of flavour. Dry and bitter finish. Body is thin and watery. Bland and boring with little character.
What an awful beer without any taste, any body, any flavor. who likes that ??

Brillant straw with small white lace.  Corn like aroma. A nice session beer that is crisp, clean, and beats the pants off of a typical american lager.  For some reason it just hit the spot on this warm windy day, and was good and cold.
Very pale, almost pure water in the glass. Nose is hay and wheat. Taste is just dry. Nothing but dry. Not being a big sushi eater, I can’t really relate to this one. Rated 5/13/04
Clear gold pour with white head. Typical corn musty lager smell. Bottle says brewed in Canada. Taste is dry with earty aftertaste.

This pale lager from Japan was actually a bit surprising. It looks and smells like an ordinary lager, but the mouthfeel is more oily, which kind of reminds me of a helles/dortmunder. Only without the flavor to back it up, rendering the Asahi Super Dry in a rather bad light. Taste is sweet and mild malts and corn syrup, with a slight metallic hint in the background. Was there a "sting" somewhere? I sure missed that; this is very far from what I’d consider "dry"... Drinkable enough, but far from a great beer.
terrible pale lager flavor, like old dish rags and sewer water. The cardboard flavor is the best part. Bottle from DRB, Miami.
cereal, grass, citrus, earthy, cooked vegetables, banana, pale, clear, frothy, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, light body, thin feel, average carbonation,

Pint from Shushi Tsu. Not sure what super dry is supposed to mean, but this just tastes like a typical American lager. Smells like pennies.  Tastes like corn and water (very un-beer-like). I prefer more flavorful beers, but whatever.
This stuff is pale yellow and i guess extra bad, not dry. The malting gives no flavor and there is nothing but water and corn...
pale yellow, thick white head.  corn, grass and sweet malts.  watery palate, corn, sweet malts and a not so appealing finish.
33 cl bottle. Clear pale yellow body with small white head. Flavour is malt, sweet and watery.

Bottle. 

Clear golden with a medium white head. Quite sweet malty aroma. Weak and watery taste. One of those fantastic pale lagers...
This is a nice fresh beer. Not strong in the taste. Tasted it frist time in Tokyo 2007, it was a hot day....
It’s OK for what it is, just not much to it. Pretty smooth, pale and dry. Drinkable in a pinch.
Tap. Another boring pale lager. Aromas of straw, and light malt. Taste is sweet, with light bitterness. Thin and watery. Light yellow, with a frothy head.
Pale yellow with a fragmented head. Aroma and flavour of rice and corn with a metallic finisg. Thin and watery, Goes best with some wasabi, I would think ...

330ml bottle. Pale amber colour, very clear with a sudsy dishwater look about the scattered bubbles that attempt to form a head. Bland and almost offensive aroma - starchy and grainy. Dry on the palate with a hint of sweetness. Very ordinary at best.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a clear golden yellow with a decent, clingy, white head that slowly fades.  Aroma and Taste are of malt, corn, rice and some hops.  A little sweet with a slight bitterness and dryness to it.  Has a good body, that isn’t too watery.  Reminds me of Molson, but foamier.  Smooth, clean and easy to drink, but is little pricey for what it is.

Clear golden colour, highly carbonated when first poured. Small white head that largely dissapears. Aroma of barley. Not much taste to speak of, quite watery. I have definetely had worse for a mass produced lager. It’s drinkable, and quite plesant in the heat.

This is slightly better than alternatives such as Heineken and Coors.  The flavor seems a little crisper to me, and the hops are slightly more pronounced.  Nothing to really note in the flavors; there’s nothing really there.

Aroma of lemon grass and hay. Appearance is golden with carbonated head that went quickly. Flavor matches the nose, with a small flash of citrus as it enters your mouth. Palate is fizzy. Nothing of note here.

Bottle. Pours a golden pale orange with a white head that quickly disappears to a thin ring. Aroma is quite lemony, some honey like sweetness, some grain. Very "short" when sipped, basically no aftertaste, just a quick rush of lemon and malt sweetness with a short dry finish. Sparkly carb, light body. Nothing tastes off here though, just bland and boring. Drinkable and refreshing is the best I can say about this.

Appearance: Pours from the bottle a clear, light yellow body with a tall, airy, white head.

Smell: Simple though agreeable aroma of lightly malted barley, rice, and a light hint of Noble hops.

Taste: Lightly sweet, mild tastes of malted barley and rice. Faint bitterness and hint of spiciness imparted by the hops. Finishes dry, crisp, and cleansingly refreshing.

Mouthfeel: Thin-bodied. Medium-plus carbonation.

Drinkability: It’s okay, really. While mild, it is clean and crisp with no discernible off-flavors - as a lager should be. I’d say it would be a good go-to beverage for pairing with sushi, but, that’s what the sake is for!

Light yellow colored with little white head. Grassy aroma with lemon, some dry cardboard here too. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is more dry with cardboard dominating, lemon also here. Well, dry as promised, nothing much more.
Bottle 33cl. Clear filtered brew with small white foam. First dry impression, then grainy-malty. Pasteurized broad aftertaste.

Bottle thanks to angrypirate06 (despite what he says). Pours with a white head and a pale golden body. Aroma of sweetness, rice, and not much else. Taste is sweet, grainy and tons of adjuncts. Super corn and rice soup. Fizzy and dry.
Bottle thanks to bman1113vr. Clear yellow pour with small white fizzy head. Aroma is rice, sweet. Flavor is cardboard, rice, sweet.

12 oz. bottle from a sushi restaurant in Northside in Cincinnati.  Pours a clear gold color with a small white head, small for the style anyway.  Aroma of corn, grains, pale malts, skunk, and light hops.  The flavor is also corny, grainy, and malty.  Light bodied, with a lot of carbonation and, as the bottle promises, a super dry finish.  Not very good.  Just something to drink with sushi, as the other options were 2 other Japanese macro pale lagers.
Clear gold with a fine  white head. Sweet peach, grass and honey aroma. Tastes of apple and grass. Refreshingly delicious.

Draft @ Bangkok airport. Deep gold, clear, nice delicate white head with decent retention. Clean, malty aroma with very light grassy hops. Very clean beer does finish dry with no lingering effects. Crisp hops in the finish. Soft gentle carbonation on the palate. Quite a good pale lager.
bottle - I bought this mainly to add the label to my collection. I wasn’t expecting much and didn’t get much. Typical asian brew more astringent than most.

Pours basic macro yellow with a white head. Aroma is that of a basic macro lager with some sweetness. Flavor is more of the same with a little more sweetness than you get with American macro lagers. You also get some hop bitterness, but it is subdued. Thin mouthfeel and highly carbonated. Not a terrible beer, but not something I think I will try again.

Pours a clear light straw with a touch of gold highlights. His white head fades rather quickly into a thin blanket which at least lingers through the majority of our session together. A steady stream of bubbles burst release a lively and crisp nose. As its namesake promised, his nose is noticeably on the dry side with lemon spritzer while grains freshly hulled from their husk are left out in the sun to dry. At the back of his nose is freshly mowed green grass drying in the sun. A flitter of key lime esters and sugar-coated lemon bars complete the nose and so, without further ado, I dive deep into his Super Dry depths. Not very dry, but his palate is faster than lightning because if I blink, I might just miss what I’m trying to taste. Like a flash, there is no front or finish to this beer, just a quick stab of flavor centered on the top of my tongue. Lemon bars, creamy grains, and a faint wisp of honey sweetness. Key lime shadows flit and flicker in the light of his quick-flash palate. Maybe that’s what the Super Dry is all about: a quick flash of flavor with nothing left to remind you of its presence. His mouthfeel is softer than I was expecting given all the Super Dry hype, which lends him a surprisingly soft and smooth mouthfeel which does little to actually dry my palate. A drain pour by no means, but through no manner of further quaffing will I discover any new lands of opportunity.




The Asahi Super Dry is alright so long as one doesn’t expect much of anything. I have concluded that Super Dry is equivalent to Super Quick which in-turn describes his palate perfectly. There was far more to enjoy in his nose than anywhere else, not by lack of flavor but by intensity of flavor with a satisfying finish.
Gold pour with white head. Light body and a clean finish, inoffensive. While a great complement for sushi/gari/wasabi, bereft on its own.

A - Hoppy 
A - Golden with white thick head
T - Slightly sweet with a light bitter finish
P - Thin with high carbonation
O - Alright beer, but nothing special

Same dinner, surprised to see a Japanese beer on an Indian dinner menu, but it was there so I figured why not.  The beer was very light in flavor, very smooth with a slight astringency that seemed to replace the sweetness found in other pale lagers.  I doubt I’d ever pick this up at a store, but for $3 a bottle, it was fine with me.

Little white vanishing head, pale clear yellow color. Little thin aroma, very short and rather unimpressive. Maybe herb and malty, if u have a trained nose. Just a bit metallic mouthfeel. Anonimous but i have drinked worse industrial beers.
Pours pale gold into a shaker. Bright white head recedes to hug rim. Corn aromas. Sharp sour corn and adjuncts. Dry finish.

Date: November 21, 2009

Mode: Bottle

Source: Tasting, Cellar Party

Appearance: pale gold, wispy white head, drippy lace

Aroma: pale malt aroma, light floral hops, faint green apple

Flavor: sweet malt flavor, floral hops, green apple

Aroma: 3/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 3/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 7/20

Rating: 1.9/5.0
Drinkability: 5/10

Score: *+ /4
Tipica lager asiatica, riso a manate, niente di buono, per apprezzarla bisogna berla dopo una cosa oscena come il nostro primo aborto da homebrewers.

Little to no aroma. Watery appearance and no head. Tastes like a downgraded Sapporo (which is already not impressive). Feels like slightly carbonated water in your mouth. Overall it just isn’t worth trying except for the fact that it’s a rice beer, which is interesting enough if you’ve never had one.
Pint.  Pours a golden color with a medium sized white head.  Not overly carbonated.  Aromas of grass, malt, and metal.  Light bodied.  A little crisp, but does go down easy.  About what I expected.

Clear straw pour, nice head and lace, rising bubbles. Sweet beery aroma. Nice carb, corny sweetness, with a touch of butter. Some hoppy dryness at the end. Smooth, drinkable, refreshing. Average pale.
11.11.2006, 0,33l Bottle. Golden yellow colour. Aroma is weak malty. low bitterness and almost no aftertaste. It is dry with some bitterness at the end.

(bottle - 12 oz) Clear gold with a thin white head. Aroma is dry grass and corn. Flavor is light and very refreshing. Mild corn and sweet malts at the beginning with a very light and grassy middle. Aftertaste is crisp and not too lingering. Really nice and refreshing.

12oz bottle and can.  Pours a bright gold color with a white foamy head.  Very mild rice aroma.  Really doesn’t have much of a flavor at all. Some rice-grain aspects, maybe a hint of hops, but really no real taste to it.  American macro qualities.

A 22 oz bottle. the beer poured a clear golden body and a foam white head. The smell is some what sweet and dry. the taste is light and dry..duh. Good carbonation.

12 pack

piss yellow with a foamy head that eventually fades away, , smells cornbready in a way, not too strong at all, taste is dry, bitter, a bit off, but weak and ricey. harsh but filling mouthfeel, idk, wont bother with again.

I guess "Asahi" is Japanese for "Budweiser."  Bottle.  Pours faintly yellow with a small fizzy head.  Little aroma, little flavor.  Vaguely malty, barely hoppy, a bit skunky.  Not offensive, but barely more appealing than water.  Your basic macro pale lager.  Not drinking this again.

Aroma = shitty draft at the bad bars, smells like beer box cardboard. You could read a book through the glass. There is something that tates like malt and maybe hops, but maybe my mind is playing tricks on me because it says beer on the can, but there might or might not be hops flavours present. Despite the cardbord theme, it is actually quite smooth. I have certainly had worse, but not that many, it’s not too offensive but this reminds me of days of yore when you might want to consider what the beer will be like on the way back out...
Pours pale yellow, white head low retention. Dull corn aroma. Tastes like cardboard, corn and filler. Tastes like any other shitty macro pale lager.

Canned, from Japan or Taiwan if I remember correctly, brought to me by FatPhil - thanks matey! Clear, pale yellow, almost no (white) head. Toilectic aroma, but I’ve tried worse. Taste like a tasteless version of some dry canned cider-pop, i.e. dull. Is there seriously corn and rice here?? Weird stuff. The only positive thing I can say are the dots for blind people on top of the can.

330 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a clear yellow-gold with small white head.  Pretty underwhelming aroma of wet grass and vegetal notes.  Flavour is almost absent.  Unbelievable.  Slight metallicness.  Light bodied with a dry/sweet finish.  Not enough flavour to be overwhelmingly awful - just really bad.

Poured a slightly cloudy pale amber with a very foamy head.  Very mild aroma-yeasty with a touch of citrus.  Palate is light and slightly fizzy.  Very mild taste.
Noted some lemon and an aftertaste reminiscent of straw.
350ml Can (Thanks FatPhil) - Golden with a large white head. Grassy aroma with grain and a hint of citrus. Sweet and malty taste with corn detected.
International lager, the best you can say about this beer is that it is dry, very dry!

I finally had this beer and was actually pleasantly surprised. Clear golden color with foamy white head. Somewhat sweet smell; smells like beer, way better than macro-US lager. Taste is pretty good. A modicum of hops. Nice dry mouthfeel. A little bit of sweetness in there as well. Better than I thought it was going to be.

Serving: 330 ml bottle.
Appearance: Clear gold color with a foamy, white head.  Lesser head retention.
Aroma: A little grain and sweet malt notes.  Relatively light.
Flavor: Sweet malt and cereal notes at first with a slight floral hop bitterness.  Simple, but I don’t see any flaws in it.
Palate: Medium-high carbonation with a light, dry mouthfeel and a short finish.
Overall: I actually think this beer is pretty solid.  With a style that shows even the most minor of flaws, I had a hard time finding any and it was pretty refreshing.

33cl bottle poured into a lager glass.  Sparkling gold to copper color with two fingers rapidly dissipating off-white head.  Aroma is faint sweet malt.  Flavor is mostly sweet malt with some hops in the background.  Finish is slightly bitter.  Boring beer.
Served from bottle. Golden yellow with a sweet aroma. Not much head. Not a reason for moving to Asia...
Pours a pale yellow. Thin body, weak hops and grain flavour. Extremely overrated generic pale lager.

Cans at my aunt and uncle’s place in Tokyo.



Gotta say, after a long tay of traveling this one goes down well. Maybe not a world class lager, but it sure hits the spot right now and does seem to be missing most of the flaws that might mar such a beer. I’m coming in way above the mean here and I think it’s partly the circumstance but hey, hedonic scale and all that.

Pours clear pale straw yellow. 
Nose of floral hops and grains. 
Taste is very thin, as name implies, a very dry body, light cereal grain flavors, light floral bop bitterness, no residual sweetness, back end rinses like water.

Tanaka of Tokyo, Hawaii, sampled the Japanese version. Wonderful, crisp , dry. 

Molson variety , not so good. Will only drink again when the real thing is available.
Sweet malty aroma. Pale amber with very little aroma. Flavour is sweetish, very dusty grain. Thin bodied and overcarbonated. Oily mouthfeel. Finishes with burnt toast. Not one bit to my taste.
Bottle. 12 oz. Pours clear yellow. Smells terrible. No head. Honestly, why do they bother brewing this rubbish? I wanted to cry after I took my first sip. Awful, awful "beer."
Pours a golden yellow with a sweet corny aroma with a hint of hops. Tastes of malted corn and bitter hops. It has a strong mouthfeel and mild effervescence.
Pretty crappy lager.  Skunky smell, crappy taste.  Stupid sushi place influences me to drink "ethnically"
Six Pack.  An Asian pale lager?  That’s about right.  Nothing really to say about it that hasn’t been said.

I found this beer surprisingly disappointing. Maybe, it’s an issue of age or something. At any rate, the beer pours a straw yellow color, a shade darker than other Japanese lagers, with a puffy white head. The head dissipates rather quickly, leaving some lacing. The shade of yellow is a bit strange, but perhaps that’s just my opinion on the flavor/aroma of the beer coloring &#40pun&#41 my feelings on the appearance. The odor is light but still off-putting. It’s on the weak end of the spectrum of macro lager aromas but definitely not the bottom of the barrel. The flavor is a mix of bitter, grassy hops, cheap super pale malt plus adjuncts &#40rice, I guess&#41 and a mildly stomach-turning sourness. The mouthfeel is light with some graininess. Drinkability isn’t horrible, either, but it’s certainly nothing to write home about. It’s light and sits easily, but I don’t think that I could finish this enormous can by myself unless I was fairly drunk and not really noticing the flavor.

From Tokyo Canada, ? YUCK.
The last pale lager I had from my beers of the world pack &#40Quilmes Cristal&#41 was kinda tasty, this is crap.  No barley or hop taste...like water + a dash of vodka that they soaked some corn in.  This should have stayed in Japan, err, Canada.

As boring as a beer can get. I find it hard to give this beer any points. I struggle to give it something. This reminds me of when I did not know there where so many beers out there that were good & I really did not care for drinking because of this stuff.

Bottle: some deli in China town, Manhattan. Pours amber, no head. accidentally served from too long in the freezer... I didn’t know beer could form ice. Has a light simple profile, the rice is obvious. Dry but not bitter. Not the best asian beer I’ve had.

12 ounce bottle from Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a clear pale golden with a thin head. Fair head retention and lacing. Sweet grainy aroma with strong corn notes. Bitter grassy taste with strong rice notes as well as corn and grain. Thin bodied.

0.33 l bottle courtesy of Doggythedog, thanks for sharing! It poured pale golden body with medium sized head. Some Asian malt and grassy hops in aroma. Flavor wasn’t really bitter, it was smooth, malty and not so typical Asian for me, as I didn’t felt any rice, just hay, honey malt. Pretty thin bodied. Aftertaste shows some hops then, metallic a bit as well. Not bad and very drinkable beer, but a bit boring.

0.33l bottle courtesy of some friends who brought it from Rome &#40huge thanks!&#41, says it’s brewed in Tokyo. Ok then. Hm, poured a pale golden body with medium sized head that went away fast. Sweaty nose with notes of alcohol, rice... slightly sweetish mess all in all. The taste is quite soft and sweetish, some bready corn, rice is also evident. Some light bite, trace herbal hopiness. Yay. A typical Asian lager, as others have said, unremarkable.
633mL bottle. Golden with next to head. Not much taste or flavour. Unremarkable.

Bottle.  Yellowish color with a fairly nice white head that lasts.  Aroma is adjunk, grain, and malt.  Flavor is pale malt, rice/corn, grain, and a little metal.  Light, dry, and crisp on the palate.  Bland, but good for sake bombs, if nothing else.
Nice grainy note.  Rather acidic finish.  Slight complexity and clean aroma.
straw pour with a small white head . tase like rice and corn. not bad it is what it is.

clear yellow, large thick creamy white head.
aroma is slightly citrussy, sweet, strange aroma as if was brwed using rice.
flavor is weaksweet and flat, rice, not refreshing.

50 cl can from Japan (thanks Dad!), served cold in a tulip glass. JL 24/09.



App.:  Clear golden with a gleaming white head.
  
Aroma:  Fairly plain grain/cereal, corn/rise, little else.
  
Palate:  Medium body and carbonation.
  
Flav.:  Also plain, a little adjunct, minerals; dry with no bitterness and a fairly watery finish.



Refreshingly bland.

Decent beer for what it is. Should be rated higher. Definitely watery and refreshing but too light on flavor. Aroma is pretty good. Bitter sweet aftertaste. Too much carbonation. Clean and nothing off. Good alternative to water.

This just wasn’t very good, maybe the worst Japanese beer I’ve had - and this one was not even made in Japan - brewed in the Czech Republic!  Go figure.  Colour was a pale yellow and the head was insigificant.  Aroma was almost non-existant, much like the flavour from this watery creation.

Can: Poured a light bright golden color lager with a large bubbly head with average retention and minimal lacing. Aroma of sweet malt with minimal adjunct being noticeable.
