Lets just say I will probably forget about drinking this beer in the morning.
Brewed in Canada.  Clean crisp highly carbonated.  .........................

This is almost as bad if not worse than some of the american water/beer experiments. The beer is watered down, the taste is sharp and unappealing, and it doesnt leave me wanting more. Dry, cardboardy...little malt presence but definitely plenty of rice. Active carbonation, but truly no other redeeming qualities.
No nose. Light gold color, head dissolves quickly. Light malt taste. Thin quick profile. Watery, but not a bad beer.
Sweet hoppy nose. Pee yellow, couldn't find a head. Little bit hoppy but watery finish. Boring!
Very pale beer with mild bitterness.  Overall quality limited by flat appearance, but better than it is currently rated.
Again, a beer for people who don't like the taste of beer. Good with sushi, but that's about it.

Sweet aroma with a bit of hops. Adjuncty wet-dog smell, too. Golden yellow color with huge frothy white head that quickly left. A little lace. Light, crisp, and refreshing. Watery and mellow. Not bitter at all. Decent middle-of-the-road beer, good with food.
An ok if somewhat bland, dry finishing beer.................................
It's the best when I had it in the brewery (in Japan)... Nothing special about it though.

I'll admit that I bought this "Japanese" beer (brewed "under supervision" in the Czech Rep.) only to get a higher score on the "most countries" rating. However I was compelled to drink it tonight (had planned to wait a bit) in order to lose the foul aftertaste of the EKU 28 I had sampled earlier. This beer is definitely contrary to the foul eisbock: It's probably the driest beer I've ever tasted. Refreshing, but not something I'd buy again (ref. Norwegian prices on imported beer), unless I should happen to visit Japan. Rerate: Actually, I DID have it again without visiting Japan: It was a nice accompaniment with a meal in a Japanese garden / restaurant in Denmark.
Watery and extremely fizzy.  Oh, and it's dry.  My least favorite of the Sapporo/Kirin/Asahi triumvirate.
Cool bottle, but an average tasting lager. Fairly weak, regular tasting beer. Nothing amazing here.
blah.  That's all I can really say.  I mean it's not terrible, but blah.....

Not much going on here. Completely mild and unremarkable. Thick head that disappeared fast, typical lager coloring. Really lacking in the taste department though. I am still waiting for that first really good Japanese beer.
Pretty standard Japanese beer.Metallic aroma.Yellow and super fizzy.Has a strange aftertaste that disappears in a second.

Strange how I see all these low ratings for this Dry. Is this because it's my first 'Dry' or because my Asahi Super Dry was brewed in the Czech Republic where they overall brew much better beers than in Asia? Anyhow ... I liked it except for the fact that it made you thirsty leaving this dry (duh!) taste in your mouth. The aroma was malty and nice hoppy, almost perfume. Golden color (not pale yellow), lots of bubbles, white frothy head. Light sweet and nice malty with a very dry finish.

Pours with a soapy, lace head that dies quickly (3 inches to virtually nothing in 30 seconds flat), and big soda-pop carbonation bubbling up.  Metallic aroma.  Some life on the palate, but still oddly limp.  Very quick finish, and oh so dry--even less flavor as I drank more.  Pretty miserable beer, in my opinion.  (Had bottled brewed in Czech Republic.)
Light hoppy aroma was my favourite part. Soft start on the tongue turns tart and "Super Dry"! Nah, horrid sourish tart middle and no finish. Over processed and bland. May be good relief for wasami.
Was warned not to try this beer but found it surprisingly pleasant!.........
My "Japanese" can of Asahi was brewed by Molson in Canada.   I enjoyed it though because I am a fan of dry beers.
’Japan Beer Imported’ - yes, but not from Japan - from the Czech Republic to the UK!  Such is the beer business...Oh, this beer is quite dry and refreshing.  Otherwise nothing special.

Bright yellow color with a fizzy white quickly dissipating head.  Faint malty bready aroma.  Crisp, light bodied, effervescent, acidic taste with a hint of sweetness.  A serviceable beer.  I drank this out of a glass that previously contained Chimay blue and red as well as Duvel without being washed between beers.  I'm not sure if this had any influence on the taste of this stuff.
No head whatsoever, which is not a good start in my book. However, the flavor showed some sweetish hops that was interesting. Finish was quite dry. At best an OK brew.

Yellow. Very crisp, effervescent and watery. "Beery" with a light, bready-malt flavor and a hint of bitterness in the middle. As the name says, it is 'Super' dry in the finish. Leaves behind nothing much... except a watery blandness. Finishes dry and bland. Might go well with some hot and spicy Japanese food.
Good smell of hops also yeast. Golden. Pleasantly bitter. Stays on the tongue in a good way. Average, but very nice with Sushi.
Pretty much meets the description. Better than typical American lagers......
A rather bland offering from Asahi. I much prefer their draft and black brews. This one seems "overprocessed", the typical curse of Japanese beers.
Light head, light carbonation and a light taste. This is another Japanese beer available domestically as an import that is brewed "under supervision" by Molson Breweries, Canada.

A very drinkable beer. It's good with a meal when you don't really want to pay attention to the beer. In my opinion, that's all most lighter colored beers are good for. For the style, it ain't bad, but it also ain't worth the price.
A random find at a dodgy club in Dunedin. Corn is noticable in the aroma. This beer tastes remarkably similar to Irish whiskey with its very dry grain flavours. "Super" dry aptly describes this one.
A light and crisp beer is the way to describe it. A good thirst quencher when water sounds boring.

Bottle (Molson version). Head is initially small, frothy/fizzy, white, fully diminishing. Body is clear light yellow. Aroma is lightly malty (grain, husks), trace hops (herbs). Flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly bitter, slightly husky. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively/fizzy carbonation. Yawn.

I can easily drink a lot of these, but why spend the money when I could just get an American macro. It would probably be a refreshing brew to have in summer, or to have with sushi...but any beer is good with sushi.
Everytime i have had this beer it seems to have an odd taste.  I would much rather drink this that the bud or coors in the cooler
Golden, carbonated-fizzy head, this bland macro beer has the quality of being horrible without quite being repugnant. Drinkable, but why bother?

This was the European version brewed in Prague by the people who also make Staropramen (god they must be proud of this). Slight hint of aroma but soon disappears. Almost tasteless except for a dry bitterness as you swallow. Tap water has more flavour than this. This is apparently the third biggest selling beer brand in the world (after Bud and Bud Light)
Remember dry beers?  Apparently the Japanese haven't either.................
Very clean and crisp - not much of a smell, but it is a very enjoyable alternative to big name american lagers (Becks, Bud) Needs more suppliers in the UK - Please
OH  most honorable  very dry,   my panda dances happily.....................
They like Budweiser in Japan...I am glad they made some improvements..I live in Japan mostly and this is my on tap beer of choice...
Pale yellow. Very light bodied, very clean, very low bitterness. Boring and industrial, but at least it works well as a thirstquencher.
Goes very well with sushi, one of my favorites..............................

Not as dry as I thought but very smooth and enjoyable.
BONZAI !!!!.........
Refreshing and crisp. Great with Sushi......................................
Bitter. Not malty at all.  Slightly alcoholic/winey taste. From the country that brought you Pokemon, thinking that it was culture... now Asahi, claiming to be beer.
super dry. cleean tasting and good with sushi...............................
Mild, but bland--overall, not good, not bad. At least it's superior to the mass market brands of many other countries, but not better than a lot of other beers in the world.

I didn't really find this to be dry.  When something is labeled as dry, I expect it to be like Canada Dry Ginger Ale.  Regardless, the Japs must like their beer like Americans if this is the #1 beer in Japan.  Two thumbs up!
Pretty weak/watery.  Japanese beers suck....................................
One of the better of the lagers that I sampled on New Years eve.  Some pleasant straw/hay like smells and tastes.  Some fruity notes, smooth, sugary.
Light and clean with an artificial dryness. Mild but pronounced lager. Goes well with food as it cleans the palate with a dry, lightly-hopped aftertaste.
Very crisp, clear and overall bland. I drank this one poured from the impressive 33oz can and found that the only noticable flavor was...well..can.
Mild, crisp, and refreshing.   Along the lines of an American lager; but with little more presence of taste, bitter, and body.
Very dry and goes down nicely with sushi.  I like it better than Sapporo or Kirin.
Great beer with Sushi. Not really as watery as it is light bodied. Get the 24 ounce bottle!
Light gold with small vanishing head . Unpleasant, unclean aroma, slightly citrus like. Under developed malt of low quality, low or no hop bitterness. Short unpleasant aftertaste.

It was light, but was a solid package. So it give it respect for that. And don't forget that this beer is super. With a label like that I was expecting a bottle with a pile of really cool tasting sand. Anyone know what asahi means.
I could drink 2 liters of this stuff in half an hour, but this by itself does not a great beer make. Heat it up and pass the wasabi.

This is an excellent drink, though perhaps not an excellent beer. In many ways it lacks the characteristics often looked for by beer enthusiasts that really add character and distinction. Asahi Super Dry goes down smooth and quick, with just a slight floral or fruity taste. To put it bluntly it should probably be considered the sports drink of the beer world. Refreshing, smooth, that pint will be gone before you know it, but it may not satisfy the beer obsessed.
"Dry" should equate to a crisp finish.  With this brew, it is just another weak and watery excuse for beer.

If you don't like this beer, you're missing the point. This beer is supposed to taste like half-water half-beer. That's the way it's marketed. Super dry is something you slam down after a good game of raquetball. It's refreshing like that. Notice Super Dry has just a bit less alcohol than regular Budweiser, but tastes 10,000,000% cleaner. A marvel of modern beer engineering.
I rated 0 for everything except for overall impression because this has no taste to speak off. It's just clean-tasting water. Great with sushi, but not good for much else.
A great beer that is always available at your local Japanese restaurant.  This is also a great party beer, as most people have not tried it, and is very agreeable to most people.
Crisp, and refreshing, but with not much flavor.  Perfect with Sushi becaese of those reasons.  Does not overpower the subtle flavor of the fish but cools off the Wasabi.
